title: CTRL0000040480 - Transcribed Interview of Robert Schornak, (February 1, 2022)

data.text: SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE THE
JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
U.S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES,
WASHINGTON, D.C.
INTERVIEW OF:
ROBERT SCHORNACK
Tuesday, February 1, 2022
Washington, D.C.
The interview in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 4:03 p.m.
Appearances:
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
ADMIN ASSISTANT AND SCHEDULER

Good afternoon.
This is a transcribed interview of Mr. Robert
Schornak conducted by the House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
on the United States Capitol pursuant to House Resolution 503.
At this time, I'd ask the witness to please state your full name and spell your last
name for the record.
Mr. Schornak.
Robert Schornak, S-c-h-o-r-n-a-k.
Thank you.

members are present.

time, could counsel for Mr. Schornak please state their name for the record.

I see you shaking your head, don't worry about it too much, I'll make sure that I clarify it

Mr. Schornak.

Okay.
Thank you.
We ask that you provide complete answers based
on your best recollection.
If the question is not clear, just ask me or whoever's asking
the question for clarification.
If you do not know the answer, please simply say so.
As we went over last time with you and like we went over with Mr. Ohm, the
select committee is a separate and independent investigation from the Department of
Justice.
is not a partner with the select committee in its investigation.
We have no involvement with the prosecutions and the Department of Justice
The select committee is also not a party to your criminal case, and is not agreeing
to submit anything on your behalf to the judge, nor can we make any representations
whether if you tell the judge you met with us that the judge will be more favorably to you
during sentencing.
We have agreed with your attorney not to share the substance of what you share

went over with you last time.
If you told us about evidence of a crime that we thought law enforcement was
unaware of, or we had reason to believe you lied during this interview, then we'd be
obligated to tell the DOJ or another appropriate law enforcement agency.
tell the judge about what you said and whether it's consistent with your prior statements
in acceptance of responsibility -- I'm sorry.
And if you
And if you tell the judge that you met with us, please understand that that may

your prior statements of acceptance of responsibility.
questions, we may get asked to respond and divulge what you said.
you aware of that as well.
If the judge starts asking you
So I want to make
I also want to remind you that it's unlawful to deliberately provide false

So for this interview, providing false information could result
in criminal penalties for false statements.
Do you understand that, Mr. Schornak?
Mr. Schornak.
I understand.
Logistically speaking, just like last time, if you need breaks, just let

Ohm or take a comfort break.
Again, so if you don't understand it, please just ask one of us to repeat it.
Mr. Schornak.
Yes.
So thank you for meeting with us then.
meeting with us today.
Mr. Schornak.
There may be several people asking you questions.
with us on January 7th, Mr. Schornak, virtually for an interview?
We'll go off camera, go on mute so you can talk to Mr.
And before we get started with the actual question, do you remember meeting
We'll take a break.

We plan to go -1wish we would've just recorded that one and we'd be good to

Understood, Mr. Schornak.
And we thank you, again, for coming

We plan to go through the same topics that we discussed

EXAMINATION.
BY
So I'll start off with just some background.
Q
How old are you?
A
Q
And where are you from, Mr. Schornak?
A
Fraser, Michigan.
Q
Where do you currently live?
A
In Roseville, Michigan.
Q
And how long have you lived there?
A
Over 10 years.
Q
Can you please tell us a little bit about your educational background?
What's the highest level of education that you've completed?
A
Well, I graduated from Fraser High School, and then I went to Macomb
Community College.
And then I graduated from Wayne State University with a
bachelor's in psychology.
Q
What do you currently do for a living?
A
I'm a business develop manager with England Logistics.
Q
And have you had any other careers?
A
I mean, careers?
I've been in sales, you know, sales and account
management, customer service.
Q
Thank you.
Are you a military veteran?
A
No, I'm not.
Q
And are you prior law enforcement?
A
No, I'm not.
Q
So now we want to shift over to the general election, and the time frame
heading into January 6th.
as we headed into January 6th.
So, in general, how would you have described your political engagement
And we'll start with just understanding better your mind set
throughout former President Trump's term?
A
Well, I would say that I was very involved politically.
I mean, not as far as,
like, I was running for office or anything like that, but I just followed it very closely, you
know.
I did not originally support Trump when he started running, but, you know, as
time went on and I saw what, you know, I thought he was about, I supported him a lot.
I went to numerous rallies to support him, you know, when he was first elected
and, again, you know, when he was going for re-election.
very involved.
Q
So, I mean, I would say I was
Just -- you said you didn't support him at first, what made you change -- I
guess, just give us a few examples of what made you want to support him after you
initially didn't support him?
A
Well, I guess, you know, I just didn't really like him personally, and I thought,
you know, he was really just doing it for him, but when I started hearing about the
policies that he was claiming he was going to support, you know, those were in line with
my conservative background.
So, you know, I figured we would give him a chance.
And he didn't, you know,
back down from the media, which, you know, I could appreciate because it seemed like
most people were scared of them.
And then when he got into office, I liked all the things that he was doing, you
know, that he was trying to do, and felt like he was trying to get our country, you know,
back on track, and thought he did, you know, really good job at that, the first 3 years.
You know, after COVID, everything kind of fell apart, but, you know, I didn't really blame
that on him.
Q
Thank you.
Did you follow the news pretty closely during his entire term or
just around the election time?
A
I mean, I would say, like, when I was still on Facebook, I followed the news
pretty closely, but it wasn't like I was following, you know, news per se like watching the
news on TV.
of read what interested me, but, you know, I would read stuff probably every day.
I would generally get news stories from Facebook and just, you know, kind
Q
You mentioned Facebook.
What sources of information, if any, did you
read to stay informed in addition to Facebook?
A
Well, most of the time, like I said, I would get stories, you know, from
Facebook, and basically click on those wherever they may be from.
lot of people do that on Face book now.
about that and, you know, that's what I would do.
You know, I think a
If they see a title that interests them, they read
Those sources were, you know, too numerous, really, to remember, but as far as
news sources go, I would say most likely conservative news places, Fox News, you know.
I can't really remember, like, all of the websites, the different websites that claimed to be
news sources anyways, but, you know, generally conservative ones is what I would follow
and read on.
Q
So when you -- it sounds like you watched news or at least from television
sources as well, was it mostly through Facebook that you would click on the news like, I
guess, the television news to watch the video clips?
A
Yeah.
Exactly.
I mean, I haven't had cable for years.
So like watching
the nightly news wasn't something that we did.
Fox News to try and get a story or a full story, because a lot of times with, you know,
Facebook posts you wouldn't really get everything.
There'd be clips, you know, 30-second clips, or couple minute clips, but couldn't
always get the full story that way.
the rest of it.
I mean, I would occasionally go on to
Q
So then, I would try to search and see if I could find
So I guess as you were clicking on news stories, did you read print
publications as well, such as, like, The Wall Street Journal and The New York Times?
A
If they had a story that interested me, I would, you know, I would click on it.
I couldn't tell you how many different sources of news I took in because it was basically
whatever interest me.
I think we discussed this last time.
You know, it's kind of -- I
forget the exact term, but basically like confirmation bias.
You know, if I would see a
story that kind of promoted the way I was thinking about something, then, you know, I
was more likely to click on that story and read it than something that would contradict,
you know, what I was believing or feeling, you know, was going on.
Q
So most of the stories you would click on were, in general, whether it was
print or television or even social media was from conservative outlets?
A
Yeah.
Or, you know, the way I thought at the time was sometimes I would
click on the news just to see what they were lying about, you know, and see kind of what
their perspective on something was, but generally, just had a distrust for the mainstream
media.
Q
So I'm going to go through -- like we did last time -- a list of social media
applications and I just want you to confirm with us whether you used it for looking at
news during President Trump's term or even after the election.
Does that make sense?
A
Yeah.
Q
Okay.
Facebook you've already mentioned that, but I just want to confirm
you looked at Facebook to browse for news?
A
Yes.
Q
What about Parler?
A
I think I opened a Parler account, but I don't think I ever used it.
Q
Reddit?
A
I'm sure I went on Reddit a few times, but I wouldn't regularly go to Reddit
and read things.
Q
Snapchat?
A
Yeah.
I mean, I -- I wasn't really into Snapchat, you know, until after
Facebook, but I wouldn't say I went there for news.
videos of my friends and family.
It was more just to look at funny
Q
What about Telegram?
A
Don't know what Telegram is.
Q
Twitter?
A
I had a Twitter, but I never really went on there.
I mean, if there was
something from Twitter on Facebook, then I would, you know, click on it and read about
it, but I very rarely ever went on Twitter.
Q
Gettr?
A
Don't know what that is.
Q
VouTube?
A
VouTube, yeah.
I mean, but again, VouTube was usually -- if there was a
VouTube video on Facebook, then I would, you know, click on it.
There were times that I
would go on VouTube to look up videos because I have it -- I have the VouTube app on my
Roku at home.
on there from time to time.
So if there was really a video I'd want to see, then, you know, I'd put it
Q
What about Discord?
A
I don't know what that is either.
Q
The Donald-Dot-Win?
A
Is that new?
I don't think so.
Q
Okay.
A
No.
Q
Wimkin, W-i-m-k-i-n?
I'm surprised I don't know about that one, but I don't recall.
Gab, G-a-b?
A
Don't know what that is.
Q
And then there's another two I didn't ask last time, but just want to make
sure we're being complete.
4chan?
A
4chan sounds familiar, but if I did, I probably didn't realize it.
Q
And then 8Kun, 8-K-u-n?
A
Doesn't ring a bell.
Q
Okay.
And just to kind of round out this section, if you had to pick one of
these sources which you relied upon the most, was it fair to say it was Facebook?
A
Yeah, for sure.
Okay.
Do any of my colleagues have any follow-up questions to
that, to those questions?
-Thanks,
Mr. Schornak.
Q
And thank you for speaking with us today,
I just had a couple of follow-up questions about what you were saying at the
beginning regarding your support for President Trump, and you mentioned that you
ended up supporting the President because his policies aligned with some of your
conservative values.
I was wondering if you could expand a little bit to explain what particularly made
you proud of President Trump while he was in office and what you thought his
accomplishments were?
A
Well, you know, the America First Agenda in general, you know, sounds
good.
Hey, put Americans first.
confusing to me.
Why that would be a question to anyone is, you know,
Why wouldn't you put your country first?
I consider myself a very
patriotic person.
I've always loved my country and felt lucky to live here.
I have not
always agreed with my government, which was, you know, kind of nice to hear from him
when he was coming in that, you know, he wasn't part of the government, and that he
was going to, you know, change things in Washington, D.C., make them more -- run more
like a business, you know, when he was talking about, you know, fixing the trade deficit,
you know, making other countries pay for our help, you know, with controlling
immigration, you know, building the wall.
care too much about that, but just controlling immigration, in general.
I think it's just part of that, but I didn't really
You know, I'm, actually, married to an immigrant, so, even though I've had news
stories about me being anti-immigrant, that's -- that's inaccurate.
immigration.
know, getting the government out of our lives and just having it run more efficiently.
You know, some other things that I thought Trump supported was, you
I don't know that all those things happened, but, you know, that's kind of a
general overview.
Q
That's really helpful thank you.
One more follow up and I'll hand it back to
What do you think some of President Trump's biggest challenges were
I just -- I was for legal
while he was in office?
A
Well, I think, you know, he had -- which was funny because, you know, the
media kind of built Trump, but then it seemed like, you know, as soon as he was running
for office, then the media was completely against him.
definitely a challenge for him.
D.C., he was obviously inexperienced with that and I think he struggled, you know, in that
aspect as well.
Great.
So I think the media was
Also, dealing with all of the political stuff in Washington,
Thank you.
That was really helpful.
Hand it back to you,
Thank you.
BY
Q
And also just to round that out and make sure we didn't miss anything, did
you follow former President Trump on social media?
A
Yes.
Q
Okay.
A
I mean, as far as I know, it was just a Face book page for Donald Trump.
And do you recall what websites you followed him on, specifically?
You know, there's probably more than one, but I think he had, like, an official Facebook
page, and then there were other pages like, you know, Patriots for Trump or, you know,
Moms for Trump.
Q
Okay.
There was, you know, a lot of them.
Thank you.
There's a bunch -- not a bunch, but there's a few
groups we wanted to talk to you about.
but we wanted to just give us a summary and what's your understanding if you're aware
of these groups.
The first one is the Oath Keepers.
We mentioned to you last time, these groups,
Were you aware of who they were around the
election time or during President Trump's presidency?
A
Well, I mean, I've been aware of the Oath Keepers for a long time.
couldn't tell you exactly how long it was.
followed one of their pages.
know, as far as just upholding their oath to protect and defend the Constitution.
know, I'm a big supporter of the Constitution.
statement, I guess you could say.
Q
I'm sure Facebook knows, but, you know, I
You know, I read stories about what they were about, you
You
So I agreed, you know, with their mission
And so, I guess, if you could just summarize, at a high level, your overall
views of the Oath Keepers at this time, how would you summarize that?
A
Well, I haven't, you know, really followed anything more about them, you
know --
Q
Sorry, before January 6th.
A
Oh.
I mean, before January 6th, I wasn't following them, you know, any
more than I was previously, just really reading stuff from their website page or their
Facebook page.
Q
I guess -- I guess did you view them favorably or unfavorably, do you recall?
A
Oh, favorably, yeah.
mind set.
Q
Thank you.
A
I didn't follow them.
I didn't hear of anything from them, like, leading up to January 6th.
I thought they had, you know, similar conservative
What about the Proud Boys?
I read stories about them.
You know, they were
kind of all over the news when all that rioting was going on, and they -- I mean, really it
seems like they just kind of went to fight them, but they were claiming that they were
there to defend them, you know.
So I -- I read stories about them.
I watched videos about them, but I was never
affiliated with them or anything like that.
Q
Okay.
What about the Three Percenters?
A
The Three Percenters, as far as I viewed them, were pretty much the same
thing as the Oath Keepers.
What I know about the Three Percenters was that their
mantra was basically that 3 percent of the American population fought the British to win
the American Revolution.
So as basically, like, 3 percent against tyranny, more or less.
Q
Got it.
Turning Point USA?
A
Yeah.
I'm definitely familiar with Turning Point USA.
Charlie Kirk goes
around to college campuses where, from what I know, they start their own chapters of
Turning Point USA, and the point, as far as I know of the organization, is to spread
conservative viewpoints on college campuses, which seemed to be overwhelmingly
liberal.
Q
Okay.
And QAnon?
A
QAnon.
Oh, gees.
Yeah, I read some stuff from QAnon.
I didn't really
follow them all that much, but it was impossible not to see their stuff on Facebook with
the pages that I was associated with.
conservative people wanted to believe.
but it was mixed together.
that did follow it and did believe it wholeheartedly, and I was -- I was always a bit
apprehensive about it because, you know, seemed a little far-fetched.
Q
Okay.
QAnon said a lot of stuff that I believe
You know, half of it was true, half of it was BS,
So it turned out to be BS.
You know, I know a lot of people
Following the 2020 election, did you believe that the election had
been stolen from former President Trump?
A
I did.
Q
What made you believe that the election had been stolen?
A
Well, that's a long conversation, but I'll try and keep it short.
You know, a
lot of it had to do with what we were being, you know, fed.
lot of irregularities with the election.
you know, drop boxes, all the laws, essentially, that were bent, you know, in order to
accommodate for COVID just made things seem really sketchy.
We knew that there were a
Because of COVID, all the mail-in voting, all the,
In addition to that, the night of the election, it seemed like Trump had won and
that, you know, that was it.
And then we wake up in the morning to find out that
they're still counting, you know, all these ballots and all these ballots are still coming in,
and that is not how elections normally go.
So it was -- it wasn't that hard to believe that the election was stolen because of
all these different individual instances where people could point to and say, Well, look at
this and look at that, you know.
Maybe -- maybe Trump's right.
And then with all the
things that they kept saying were going to be exposed and were going to come out in
court and elsewhere, you know, and we wanted to believe it.
Q
So --
So did you start to believe the election was stolen pretty immediately like
that night and the morning after?
A
Well, yeah.
I mean, especially once they declared Biden the winner, you
know, we -- we thought that was impossible, but, you know, the fact -- it wasn't just those
things as well.
It was also statistical anomalies -- you know what I'm trying to say.
Q
I got it.
A
Yeah.
Yeah.
You know, things that had never happened before that did
not seem possible, you know, or at least probable.
constantly being shot at us as evidence.
Q
And those things were, you know,
And, you know, we wanted to believe it.
So talking about the evidence that was being shot at you, was this evidence
coming from former President Trump himself, that he was saying?
A
Well, he was definitely saying a lot, but he had more people saying stuff for
him, I think, than he was actually out there saying.
people on the news, talk radio, and then, of course, you know, the websites that were
just putting information out left and right.
Q
You know, his lawyers, different
Yeah, I mean -- we did believe it, obviously.
Were there any specific people, or groups of people, that were more
influential for you during this time as far as believing the election had been stolen?
A
Well, yeah.
I mean, more influential?
It was kind of just a combination,
but, you know, I remember when Trump's lawyers were coming out and they were, you
know, suing everybody, you know, we thought that, hey, that stuff' s going to work.
I don't know that any of it did.
Obviously, it didn't, but, you know, it's just -- it
kept coming, you know.
One thing after another, it seemed like, you know, was coming
out or being discussed.
So it really wasn't that hard for us to believe it.
Q
Following the election during this period when the rhetoric about the
election being stolen was being pushed out, did you attend any rallies immediately after
the election in Michigan or elsewhere?
A
Yeah.
Yeah.
I attended one in Detroit.
I attended one in Lansing.
mean, it might have even been more than one in Lansing, but I know at least one in each
of those places, you know, neither of which were really that big.
remember, you know, too much happening there besides what normally happens.
I mean, I don't
Q
Were these Stop the Steal rallies?
A
Yes.
Q
Okay.
A
Well, I mean, I don't know if they were called that, so I don't want -- I don't
And what, I guess --
want to, you know, say the wrong word there, but that's what they were about was the
election and how we thought that they were being stolen.
were called Stop the Steal rallies, but that's what they were about.
So I don't know that they
Q
And what drew you to these rallies in Detroit and in Lansing?
A
Well, just the fact that I had believed, you know, that the election was being
stolen and that, you know, we needed to protest against it.
wasn't -- it wasn't that hard for me to go to Detroit and Lansing, but neither were really
that long either.
Q
Right.
I definitely believed it, so it
Before I open it up for any of my colleagues to ask questions, you
didn't go to the November 14th rally in Washington, D.C., correct?
A
No, I did not.
Q
And you didn't attend the December 12th rally in Washington, D.C. either?
A
No.
Q
Were you aware of violence occurring at one of the rallies in D.C. at this
time?
Were you tracking that?
A
I don't recall that.
Okay.
questions for Mr. Schornak?
BY
Q
Thanks, yeah.
If it's all right, I'd like to follow up with a couple of questions
about your beliefs that the election had been stolen for our background and context.
So you mentioned that you went to an event in Detroit.
Does any other staff members have any follow-up
Could you speak
specifically about why you chose to go to an event in Detroit and in Lansing?
A
Well, yeah.
We had believed that the Detroit election had fraud in it.
My
brother was actually one of the people that was counting votes there that day.
I went
down there that day as well, and, you know, what we had been hearing was that people
were not being allowed to do their job in trying to count the votes.
People had said that they were bringing in additional votes and they were all for
Biden.
was, you know, one of the places that was most highly involved in the fraud that we
believed was going on.
You know, I read that and heard that.
So, you know, we thought that Detroit
You know, that's why I went down to Detroit.
As far as Lansing goes, I think that was just, you know, another rally.
You know,
someone invited me, or let me know about it, or I read about it, and Lansing's only like an
hour from my house, so it's not that far for me to go to.
Q
And just to clarify, you may have already said this, so apologies.
When was
the event in Detroit that you went to?
A
The event that I went to in Detroit was right after.
it was the day after.
If it wasn't the next day,
Q
Okay.
A
I mean, not the next day after the election, but it was really close to after the
election ended.
guess, but I don't remember exactly which day.
You know, probably when they were finalizing the vote total, I would
Would you remember if it was at a vote counting center or was it
Q
somewhere else?
A
Yeah.
Q
The TCF Center?
A
Yep.
Q
And can you tell us a little bit more about what people were saying, the
It was right outside.
speakers you saw there?
A
Well, I wasn't really paying attention to them.
To be honest, I was talking
with other people, but, you know, they were saying things like, you know, they're stealing
the election.
witnesses to the fraud, you know, and they had people there, you know, that were talking
about what they saw inside, how they were being treated inside, you know.
You know, fraud was committed right here in this building.
Q
Is it people who were trying to be poll observers?
A
Yeah.
Q
Observing the election count?
Got it.
We have
So who do you think was
responsible for the coordinating the fraud in Michigan, in Detroit, specifically?
A
Well, I mean, as far as I know, there wasn't any.
Q
Uh-huh.
A
You know, we don't -- don't have any real proof of it, you know.
They -- there was --
Q
I should clarify, at the time, what did you think?
It was just perception.
A
Well, at the time, we believed that people were bringing in votes and that
they weren't being verified because the poll watchers were not allowed to look at them.
And when they insisted on seeing them, they were basically bullied and, you know, some
were even kicked out.
Q
Just a couple more questions on this.
Thank you for your explanation.
It's
really helpful for us.
My next question is, why did you think that Detroit and Lansing were particularly
susceptible to this kind of fraud?
A
Well, I don't know anything about Lansing, in particular.
It's just the
capital, so that's where they had the rally.
Q
Okay.
So Detroit then.
Why did you think Detroit was the center of this
fraudulent activity?
A
was happening.
same problems where poll watchers weren't allowed to actually watch it, you know.
Well, I mean, I don't know why it was, but it just seemed like that's where it

mean, I guess I can't say every single thing that we believed isn't true, but none of it
